content.description: Fairly exciting moves for a 5.7+ sport route. Good variety of moves.
content.location: On second tower, left of Lullabye League.  Goes up to precarious-looking giant peanut.

content.description: Mostly easy climbing (5.8 or so) with one hard move at the crux bulge.  The move is fairly height-dependent but is pretty near a bolt.  Other than the crux, the route feels easier and less sustained than most of the 5.9s here.
content.location: Second route on the first wall, just off the descent trail.  Just right of orange-colored 5.11.

content.description: Couple harder moves low and through the middle, then easy above.  I kept the rating 5.10a to go with the consensus, but this is the easiest 10 I've done.  I think "Clip Clip Here..." is harder, so I'd probably go 5.9 on this one.  Fun either way.
content.location: Left of the chimney (Miss Gultch).  Starts from ledge.

content.description: Fairly sustained climbing, no one definite crux.  One guidebook gives this no stars, but it's pretty fun and well worth doing.
content.location: Second route on second tower, right of the arete (The Dark Side of Oz).  Chains are just left of the giant hanging peanut.  You can actually stand one foot on the peanut while at the anchors, if you trust it.

content.description: Stem up chimney then onto right face.  Fun to watch new climbers fresh from the gym try to face climb one of the walls.  More fun to watch your short-legged friends get butt-cheek-cramps while stemming.
content.location: In wide chimney between first two towers.  Bolts go up right side then onto face.

content.description: Fun climb with a harder start and decent exposure.
content.location: Rightmost route on the second tower, immediately left of short wall with 5.4.
Left route on the low wall past the first two towers.

content.description:
Another good first or second lead.  I still enjoy ropegunning it for people, so it's a fun warmup even if you climb higher grades. 

  There is one tricky height-dependant (but protected) move to a hidden hold up high.  Makes things interesting if you are under about 5'6".  Watch for the pointy branch behind your head at the anchors. 

  There were a couple wiggly holds on this route in June, 2006.  Nothing loose, and the belayer is well clear of the climber, but something to bear in mind.
content.location: Right route on the lower wall past the first two towers.  Goes up and right onto the arete of the main wall.

content.description: Very fun route with good exposure up a slightly overhanging arete.
content.location: Leftmost route on the second tower, on the arete right of the chimney.

climbs.name: Clip Clip Here, Clip Clip There

content.description: Excellent climb, fairly sustained and tall with a very fun roof/bulge near the end.
content.location: Third route on the first wall, just off the descent trail.  Located on the corner, starts pretty much in the tree.

content.description: Thin, slightly overhanging face climbing.  Sustained most of the way up--relents a little at the end.
content.location: First route at the bottom of the approach trail.  Climbs obvious orange stain.

content.description: The Towers area refers to section of routes located on the far left end of the Munchkin Wall. This is the first bit of climbworthy rock you encountery coming down the rocky switchbacks at the end of the approach trail. You'll see a big dark alcove/cleft in the rock where the routes are located to the left and right. Situated at 7000', it faces northwesterly and is generally shaded until around noon in the summer making for a reasonably comfortable experience even when it's quite hot. For all intents and purposes, this is part of the Munchkin Wall and you can easily mix and match routes from this area and Munchkin throughout a day of climbing.
